intro: Hyssopus ambiguus, commonly known as wild hyssop, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite leaves that are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs. Its small, tubular flowers are usually blue to purple in color and bloom in clusters during the summer months. Hyssopus ambiguus is often found in rocky soils and open woodlands, and it has been used historically for its medicinal properties.
